Elliotte Harold wrote:
> alpanhell wrote:
> 
> 
>>Am I missing something here?
> 

I think the OP is asking why you even need to do setup before each test 
- the OP only needs setup ONCE before all the tests run.

The answer to that question is that junit was designed for TDD where it 
is important that all the tests be independent.

> 
> Not really. setUp and tearDown are fundamentally weird, and way 
> overemphasized in the JUnit tutorials. They're only a couple of corner 
> cases where they matter. Specifically:

I disagree.

> 
> 1. If you need to initialize static data before each test. Instance data 
> can be initialized in the constructor because JUnit creates a new, clean 
> object for each test.
> 

Using setUp() is intention-revealing and reduces duplication in the tests.

Using the constructor to set up the fixture :

a) relies on the implementation detail that a new object is created for 
each test (I got bitten by this in the switch from NUnit1.0 to NUnit2.0).

b) if the set up is expensive it makes the startup sequence of JUnit 
long. The 'perceived ' performance is better if the expense is 
distributed across the tests rather than taken up front.

c) can introduce weird bugs if the constructor initializes statics.

Kevin
